messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: states/countries with no restrictions/laws on homeschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ... And there are a few states with no homeschooling law. So they are easy places to completely freely unschool with no interference of any kind - but people
messages.messageBody:
On Sep 13, 2004, at 7:28 AM, soggyboysmom wrote:

> *disclaimer: this is based strictly on what is written in the laws.
> Some places may have strict laws which are laxly enforced. Also,
> someplaces may be legally unrestricted but have a lot of DCS
> interference.

And there are a few states with no homeschooling law. So they are easy
places to completely freely unschool with no interference of any kind -
but people operate as private schools, not home schools. And there are
other places with homeschooling law, but also the option of private
school freedom.

-pam
National Home Education Network
<www.NHEN.org>
Serving the entire homeschooling community since 1999
through information, networking and public relations.

messages.subject: Re: states/countries with no restrictions/laws on homeschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ... Well, CT has none - not even Notice of Intent required. Top 10 easy places in US in alphabetical order AK, CT, DC, ID, IL, IN, MI, NJ, OK, TX. I think
messages.messageBody:
--- In UnschoolingDiscussion@yahoogroups.com, "moonwindstarsky"
<moonwindstarsky@y...> wrote:
> couldn't remember where the post was

Well, CT has none - not even Notice of Intent required. Top 10 easy
places in US in alphabetical order AK, CT, DC, ID, IL, IN, MI, NJ,
OK, TX. I think there are a couple of provinces in Canada that are
also pretty hands-off but don't have details handy.

*disclaimer: this is based strictly on what is written in the laws.
Some places may have strict laws which are laxly enforced. Also,
someplaces may be legally unrestricted but have a lot of DCS
interference.
